description: From Middle English bed, bedde, from Old English bedd, from Proto-West Germanic *badi, from Proto-Germanic *badją.

definitionGroups.group: A piece of furniture, usually flat and soft, on which to rest or sleep.

entries.meaning: A prepared spot in which to spend the night.
examples: When camping, he usually makes a bed for the night from hay and a blanket.

entries.meaning: (usually after a preposition) One's place of sleep or rest.
examples: Go to bed!
I had breakfast in bed this morning.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, usually after a preposition) Sleep; rest; getting to sleep.
examples: He's been afraid of bed since he saw the scary film.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, usually after a preposition) The time for going to sleep or resting in bed; bedtime.
examples: I read until bed.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Time spent in a bed.
(figurative) Marriage.
examples: George, the eldest son of his second bed.

entries.meaning: (figurative, uncountable) Sexual activity.
examples: Too much bed, not enough rest.

entries.meaning: Abbreviation of bedroom.
examples: 2 beds, 1 bath

definitionGroups.group: A place, or flat surface or layer, on which something else rests or is laid.

entries.meaning: The bottom of a body of water, such as an ocean, sea, lake, or river. [from later 16thc.]
examples: sea bed
river bed
There's a lot of trash on the bed of the river.

entries.meaning: An area where a large number of oysters, mussels, other sessile shellfish, or a large amount of seaweed is found.
examples: Oysters are farmed from their beds.

entries.meaning: A garden plot.
examples: We added a new bush to our rose bed.

entries.meaning: A foundation or supporting surface formed of a fluid.
examples: A bed of concrete makes a strong subsurface for an asphalt parking lot.

entries.meaning: The superficial earthwork, or ballast, of a railroad.
The platform of a truck, trailer, railcar, or other vehicle that supports the load to be hauled.
examples: Synonym: tray
The parcels were loaded onto the truck bed before transportation.

entries.meaning: A shaped piece of timber to hold a cask clear of a ship’s floor; a pallet.
(printing, dated) The flat part of the press, on which the form is laid.
(computing) The flat surface of a scanner on which a document is placed to be scanned.
A piece of music, normally instrumental, over which a radio DJ talks.
(darts) Any of the sections of a dartboard with a point value, delimited by a wire.
(trampoline) The taut surface of a trampoline.
A deposit of ore, coal, etc.
(geology) The smallest division of a geologic formation or stratigraphic rock series marked by well-defined divisional planes (bedding planes) separating it from layers above and below.
examples: Synonyms: layer, stratum

entries.meaning: (masonry) The horizontal surface of a building stone.
examples: the upper and lower beds

entries.meaning: (masonry) The lower surface of a brick, slate, or tile.
(masonry) A course of stone or brick in a wall.

verbs.description: bed (third-person singular simple present beds, present participle bedding, simple past and past participle bedded)

definitionGroups.group: Senses relating to a bed as a place for resting or sleeping.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go to bed. I usually listen to music before I bed.
(transitive) To place in a bed.
examples: For she was not only publicly contracted, but stated as a bride, and solemnly bedded, and after she was laid, there came in Maximilian's ambassador with letters of procuration

entries.meaning: To put oneself to sleep.
(transitive) To furnish with a bed or bedding.
(transitive, intransitive) To have sexual intercourse with. [from early 14th c.]
examples: Synonyms: coitize, go to bed with, sleep with; see also Thesaurus:copulate with

definitionGroups.group: Senses relating to a bed as a place or layer on which something else rests or is laid.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lay or put in any hollow place, or place of rest and security, surrounded or enclosed; to embed.
examples: Among all chains or clusters of mountains where large bodies of still water are bedded.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set in a soft matrix, as paving stones in sand, or tiles in cement.
(transitive) To set out (plants) in a garden bed.
(transitive) To dress or prepare the surface of (stone) so it can serve as a bed.
(transitive) To lay flat; to lay in order; to place in a horizontal or recumbent position.
To settle, as machinery.
